question: What is a stateless file server?
options: ['a) It keeps tracks of states of different objects', 'b) It maintains internally no state information at all', 'c) It maintains some information in them', 'd) None of the mentioned']
option1: a) It keeps tracks of states of different objects
option2: b) It maintains internally no state information at all
option3: c) It maintains some information in them

question: What are the characteristics of the stateless server?
options: ['a) Easier to implement', 'b) They are not fault-tolerant upon client or server failures', 'c) They store all information file server', 'd) They are redundant to keep data safe']
option2: b) They are not fault-tolerant upon client or server failures
option3: c) They store all information file server
option4: d) They are redundant to keep data safe

question: Implementation of a stateless file server must not follow?
options: ['a) Idempotency requirement', 'b) Encryption of keys', 'c) File locking mechanism', 'd) Cache consistency']

question: What are the advantages of file replication?
options: ['a) Improves availability & performance', 'b) Decreases performance', 'c) They are consistent', 'd) Improves speed']

question: What are characteristic of NFS protocol?
options: ['a) Search for file within directory', 'b) Read a set of directory entries', 'c) Manipulate links and directories', 'd) All of the mentioned']
option1: a) Search for file within directory
option2: b) Read a set of directory entries

question: What is the coherency of replicated data?
options: ['a) All replicas are identical at all times', 'b) Replicas are perceived as identical only at some points in time', 'c) Users always read the most recent data in the replicas', 'd) All of the mentioned']
option1: a) All replicas are identical at all times
option2: b) Replicas are perceived as identical only at some points in time
option3: c) Users always read the most recent data in the replicas

question: What are the three popular semantic modes?
options: ['a) Unix, Coherent & Session semantics', 'b) Unix, Transaction & Session semantics', 'c) Coherent, Transaction & Session semantics', 'd) Session, Coherent semantics']

question: What are the characteristics of Unix semantics?
options: ['a) Easy to implement in a single processor system', 'b) Data cached on a per process basis using write through case control', 'c) Write-back enhances access performance', 'd) All of the mentioned']
option1: a) Easy to implement in a single processor system
option2: b) Data cached on a per process basis using write through case control

question: What are the characteristics of transaction semantics?
options: ['a) Suitable for applications that are concerned about coherence of data', 'b) The users of this model are interested in the atomicity property for their transaction', 'c) Easy to implement in a single processor system', 'd) Write-back enhances access performance']
option1: a) Suitable for applications that are concerned about coherence of data
option2: b) The users of this model are interested in the atomicity property for their transaction
option3: c) Easy to implement in a single processor system

question: What are non characteristics of session semantics?
options: ['a) Each client obtains a working copy from the server', 'b) When file is closed, the modified file is copied to the file server', 'c) The burden of coordinating file sharing is ignored by the system', 'd) Easy to implement in a single processor system']
option1: a) Each client obtains a working copy from the server
option2: b) When file is closed, the modified file is copied to the file server
option3: c) The burden of coordinating file sharing is ignored by the system
option4: d) Easy to implement in a single processor system
